item.title: Sending email with AWS Simple Email Service (SES) and Python
item.description: Sending email with AWS Simple Email Service (SES) and Python The first thing we need is our AWSCLI credentials. Having multiple profiles in the AWSCLI credentials file, we need to set our credentials when we instantiate the boto3 client. So we have a simple dict in a file we will import. # boto3_credentials.py boto3_credentials = { 'aws_access_key_id':'<YOUR_ACCESS_KEY_ID>', 'aws_secret_access_key':'<YOUR_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY>', 'region_name':'us-east-2' } Here is our SESEmail class. It takes a credentials dict, a paramaters dict, and a debug boolean to instantiate.

item.title: How to write comments in markdown
item.description: How to write comments in markdown This is super simple but, I mention it because I’ve been wanting a way to put comments into some of my markdown documents. I came across this solution today and it seems to work well at least in Hugo. Using link labels to achieve it: [comment]: <> (this is how to make a md comment) reference: stackoverflow post
